subject: RE: [junit] RE: Separate Package for Test Cases or not ?
msgSnippet: ... suggest ... rule ... This seems like a pretty weak argument to me.  They only document the set of the API that the authors chose to test, and they only
messageBody:
"David Stagner" wrote:
> Unit tests document API usage very well, for starters. And they
suggest
> where any bugs encountered might be, even by their absence (a
> problematic condition may not be tested, and a set of tests could
rule
> out a bunch of possible causes for a bug).
>

This seems like a pretty weak argument to me. They only document the
set of
the API that the authors chose to test, and they only test to the
authors'
degrees of comfortability. Truth be known, just because JUnit is in use
does
not mean that the code is being tested thoroughly. Right? You may be
right
that it could show you what isn't tested, but not necessarily why. And
it only
gives you a clue as to what is not tested and what is. There may not be
a one
to one mapping of the public API to the tests.

> Heck, i'd be happy if vendors would ship a set of tests to run on
their
> software in an actual customer environment, just to catch known
problems
> (such as conflicts and naming issues). Open source projects should
> include unit tests, of course. :}
>

Can't (or don't want to) argue with this. :)

-jason
